transcripts.text: This administration, in my view, has an absolute disregard for the law.
The Mueller report makes a very strong case on obstruction of justice.
Were the president anybody other than the president, he would have been subject to indictment.
My name is Jeffrey Harris.
My name is Paul Rosenzweig.
My name is Donald Ayer.
I was the Deputy Associate Attorney General in the Reagan administration.
I was a Republican appointee at the Department of Homeland Security.

And I served as Deputy Attorney General under George H.W.  Bush.  Today the Attorney General William Barr sent Congress this four-page letter outlining the key findings of Robert Mueller's investigation.
I thought that the Barr summary seemed like a summary that should be given due thought and respect.  I was certainly willing to give the Attorney General the benefit of the doubt.
I read Bill Barr's initial letter and I was prepared to look at the report if I ever saw it and conclude that, well, there just wasn't the evidence there.
When I finally had an opportunity to read the Mueller report itself, I realized that the Barr summary was not a fair and accurate summary of what the Mueller report contained.
In the Mueller report, there is a damning case of obstruction of justice by the president.
The second volume identifies 10 or 11 instances in which the special counsel examined the question of obstruction of justice.
As a former prosecutor, I did not think that it was even a close prosecutorial call as to whether the president obstructed justice.
Obstruction of justice and perjury are far more important than most normal crimes.  They go to the absolute core of how the rule of law functions in this society.
Obstruction of justice is any act that someone does to interfere with an investigation being conducted by an official of the Justice Department, members of Congress.

The system itself is designed to find the truth.  Obstruction of justice undercuts the very foundations of the trial system, of the jury system, by denying the people who are going to decide what happened access to the truth.

Immediately after the president takes office, he begins to interfere in the Russian investigation.  The first thing he does is he tries to influence the head of the FBI, James Comey, in asking him to go easy on Michael Flynn.  And when that doesn't work out, he fires James Comey and says he's doing it because of the Russian investigation.
When I decided to just do it, I said to myself, I said, you know, This Russia thing with Trump and Russia is a made-up story.

You then had very shortly thereafter the appointment of the special counsel Robert Mueller.  The president then actively involved himself in trying to prevent Mueller from becoming the special counsel and then ultimately to be removed.
The most notable obstructive act was the president's instruction to his White House counsel, Don McGahn, to fire Mr.  Mueller.
McGahn refused to do it.
And then the president asked Don McGahn to put a false document in the file saying that the president never ordered him to fire Bob Mueller.
Asking a witness to lie to create a false record is a classic case of obstruction of justice.

was the president actively being involved to affect the testimony and the cooperation of critical witnesses, being Paul Manafort, Michael Flynn, and Michael Cohen.  The question was asked about pardons, and I said, no, I have not offered any pardons.  And I think they asked, would you?  I said, I'm not taking anything off the table.
The efforts to control the testimony of Paul Manafort and Michael Cohen by offering them or dangling in front of them pardons were almost assuredly obstructive acts.

The Mueller report revealed a picture of the president and his presidency in a way which ought to concern anyone that cares about the honest workings of government.  If the rule of law stands for nothing, then we have anarchy.  It's as simple as that.

One of the most disturbing things to me is the conduct of republicans in the senate and in the house.  these are actually smart people.  they know that there is a damning case in the muller report of obstruction of justice by the president and they are acting like it's not and that's just flatly dishonest.  And they seem to be doing it because they think President Trump is the only game in town.

The rule of law that I understand to be the core of a conservative American principle is one that requires consistency across time.  It means that you apply the same rules to everybody and that you don't change your view of the law based upon partisan political advantage.  Conservatives are all about conserving.  conserving history, conserving morality, conserving the country.  If you really believe in those sorts of principles, now is the time to put your principles first.  It's not a time to sit silent.
